choices.C: highest VLAN ID that is configured and set to YES to use VPN
choices.A: highest VLAN ID that is configured and set to NO to use VPN
choices.D: lowest VLAN ID configured and set to NO to use VPN
choices.B: lowest VLAN ID that is configured and set to YES to use VPN

questions.question_text: Which VLAN is used to source pings across the site-to-site VPN when using the MX Live tools?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Correct is: C

But we have to be in mind what follows bellow !

Behavior - Firmware MX 15.11 or Lower
For MXs running firmware MX15.11 or below, the source IP that MX uses while pinging a destination is the MX IP of highest VLAN ID. If the destination is across a VPN, the MX uses the MX IP of highest VLAN ID participating in VPN.

Behavior - Firmware MX 15.12 or Higher
For MXs running firmware MX 15.12+, additional ping options have been added to the live tool. The ping tool now has a drop down to select the source IP address for pinging destinations from the MX.
Default. The MX uses the route table to dynamically choose the ping source IP address closest to the destination IP entered.
Site-to-site VPN example: If you input a destination IP that resides across a site-to-site VPN, the MX will source the ping from the MX VLAN interface IP of the highest VLAN ID that is participating in the VPN

Selected Answer: C
See Behavior - Firmware MX 15.11 or Lower section
For MXs running firmware MX15.11 or below, the source IP that MX uses while pinging a destination is the MX IP of highest VLAN ID. If the destination is across a VPN, the MX uses the MX IP of highest VLAN ID participating in VPN. For MXs running firmware MX 15.12+, additional ping options have been added to the live tool. The ping tool now has a drop down to select the source IP address for pinging destinations from the MX.


https://documentation.meraki.com/General_Administration/Tools_and_Troubleshooting/Using_the_Ping_Live_Tool

Selected Answer: B
The error message “NotNow” is seen in the Event Log on an iOS device's details page when an action cannot be performed because the device is locked with a passcode. These actions include pushing managed apps, installing profiles, and other actions. When this occurs the device will attempt to re-connect with the MDM server as soon as the device is unlocked in order to retry the action. 

https://documentation.meraki.com/SM/Monitoring_and_Reporting/Status_of_%22NotNow%22_in_Systems_Manager_Event_Log

choices.A: The application requires the most recent iOS version.
choices.C: The device cannot connect to Apple servers.
choices.D: The device cannot connect to Cisco Meraki servers.
choices.B: The device is locked with a passcode.

choices.E: The custom application uses HTTPS on port 8080.
choices.C: The custom application uses HTTPS on TCP 443.
choices.A: The custom application uses TLS on any ports.
choices.B: The custom application uses HTTP on port 8080.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
MI will only monitor HTTPS traffic (TCP port 443), and that ports cannot be specified. For HTTP, any port can be monitored including port 8080. While the default port for HTTP traffic is 80, port 8080 can be used to avoid conflicts with other services or to run multiple web servers on the same machine.

Selected Answer: BC
Answer: B and C
monitor HTTPS traffic (TCP port 443), and that ports cannot be specified. For HTTP, any port can be monitored.

Selected Answer: BC
BC should be correct
